comments.commentBody:
You forget that the puzzle links were wrong and when I reported it, Jim yelled at me. My theory is that DST is going kicking and screaming.

Still no avatars.
Well, tonight, Amy's Blog is blank, Rex is late and Martin can't see my avatar. Right.

I don't get the either/or of "do I want to give birth or do I want to be a parent."  She wants to do both!   I don't believe that because Amy is focussing on getting pregnant that means she has not thought through the long journey of parenthood.  Did she say that?  She desires a biological child.  That does not make here stupid or unthinking.

I come from a family of seven, and one of my (biological) sisters is severely handicapped, requiring special (and very expensive) care for life. It aged my parents prematurely and nearly broke our family apart.
I also have a daughter, adopted at 15 months, who is stunning, highly intelligent, musically gifted, and sweet. Having a child is a risk, whether you gave birth to him or not.

Many women look forward to and enjoy pregnancy.  I didn't love it but I'm grateful it happened for me and I received the gift of healthy children.  Pregnancy is a real experience and I hope Amy Klein gets to have it since it seems very important to her.  If she is not successful, I hope she finds another path to parenthood and that it is a good experience.  I didn't suffer infertility so I feel I have no right to judge Amy's feelings or choices.  I only wish her well.

You’re right, Vashti. Some of the best ways to get money into the economy is through the food stamp program, unemployment benefits, and infrastructure spending. Tax breaks for the wealthy and corporations are the least effective way to create jobs.

Stimulus benefit for each dollar spent:
$0.29 – Bush income tax cuts
$0.30 – Corporate tax cut
$0.37 – Dividend and capital gains tax cuts
$1.36 – Aid to states
$1.59 – Infrastructure spending
$1.64 – Unemployment benefits
$1.73 – Food stamps

Bang for Your Stimulus Buck
http://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/10/29/bang-for-your-stimulus-buck/

With the real unemployment rate at 13.8 percent, we could create more jobs if Washington reined in wasteful military spending. Why does the U.S. spend almost as much as all other countries combined? It’s simply corporate welfare.

The “defense” sector is not labor intensive. Infrastructure projects create 40 percent more jobs per dollar than spending on the military, health care creates 70 percent more jobs, and education creates 240 percent more jobs.

Your comment calls to mind a conversation I once had with some corporate leaders who were making the case that there just wasn't enough money to provide employees with defined benefit retirement benefits.

Immediately after leaving that meeting, I stumbled across a news item stating that corporate profits were at an all-time high (that was several all-time highs ago).

Of course, the reality is that it is a lack of political will that prevents America from caring for its sick or providing for its retirees, just as it is a lack of political will that prevents us from paying people who work a living wage. There's plenty of money for all of that and more -- or there would be if a few corporate leaders didn't insist on being paid 500 or so times the average wage of their employees.

The more I study poverty and economics the more convinced I become that providing for the poor makes good economic sense for all of us. Since the Wall Street debacle of 2008 our economy has limped along because of a lack of demand. With private debt load too high and too few jobs this lack of demand gives business no incentive to invest. Giving tax cuts to the rich is counterproductive because under the current circumstances they either sit on their money or play the derivatives ponies neither of which help expand the economy.. With the poor, every dollar they receive is spent thereby generating demand for the whole economy.. There is also a multiplier effect when a poor person spends a buck. It goes round and round before it comes to rest in some rich guy's pocket.
It's already been calculated that cutting back on food stamps will actually hurt the economy. If we as a country were smart we'd up the amount of money we are giving out for food stamps. Oh, and we'd go to universal single payer health care so that the poverty caused by medical bankruptcy would go away.
Who knew that good Biblical theology would make for good economics.

This column is spot on.  By reducing the functionality of its government, the U.S. undercuts its international influence and prestige. And if you want to see progress in energy efficiency, water efficiency and manufacturing technology, visit Singapore, Taiwan and Korea.  The irony of this is that Singapore, Taiwan and Korea are using public dollars to import these technologies from the U.S. and EU, while Western societies are falling behind under austerity regimes.

You forget that the puzzle links were wrong and when I reported it, Jim yelled at me. My theory is that DST is going kicking and screaming.

Still no avatars.

There are almost 500 comments on this topic.  A few years ago I attended a high school reunion (I'm in my 60's).  A few of the men had kids 7 or 8 years old meaning they were born when these men were already in their 50's.  No one batted an eye.  I didn't hear any criticism.  Funny how a woman's choices and thoughts can generate so much controversy.

There's one more driver of the legalization of gambling and marijuana: the need to create more jobs and tax revenues as GOP austerity takes hold.  The impetus behind the legalization of casinos and soft drugs is overwhelmingly economic.  That impetus would be weakened if economic growth was enhanced on spending for infrastructure, education and health care.  But absent that, we're reduced to creating economic activity from vice.
My secret's out, John. I missed you.

Let us be honest. Those in congress complaining about the ACA have government sponsored healthcare.They are living large off the government tit. They know few if any people who don't have health care so it doesn't matter to them. The working poor and the underinsured mean nothing to them and don't contribute to their campaigns and therefore don't exist for them. As far as young people not needing health coverage, they don't need it until they do. That is when they find out they have a lousy policy and then they hope that the taxpayer picks up the tab for them. It is too expensive to do healthcare that way.
Deb, now I can go to bed and sleep tight.

I'm a CASA volunteer.  In Texas the state hasn't been all that great at making sure foster kids get into college.  It's getting better.  There is so much need for volunteers to help kids close to aging out of the foster care system.  I wish more folks would reach out and help these young people.  The "system" has let so many down already.  If you can, reach out and try to make a difference.
Ah, yes, the money will follow--some of the time; and now and then the Tooth Fairy will also follow through.  Meanwhile, Professor, sometimes your doorman will call you Doctor.

Like Tom and his wife, I obtained my PhD because it was a job requirement to be an independent scientist. I landed the increasingly elusive tenure-track position at a large research institution. At dinner last night, two colleagues and I discussed other career prospects, as we our each considering lives and careers outside the academy. Imagine actually living where one wants, not where one gets a job!

"...they want higher pay or more direct engagement with the world than monographs and tenure committees seem to allow."

That really hit home for me, as I have grown weary of the publication process. I believe it wastes far more time, energy and productivity than the improvement to manuscripts it makes. The work of government scientists is sometimes made fun of when it is published in the so-called gray literature, which often gets a softer, gentler internal review. I think they are the smart ones. Less time catering to the whims of Reviewer #2 means more time for actually engaging in science.

What? Carson's wife had an affair with Frank Gifford?

Next someone will publish a revelation that Sinatra was unfaithful to his four wives...

Disagree.

Technology is allowing the exposing of hypocrisy in starkly specific terms

There is more than entertaining Schadenfreude in this column. It reveals the harsh truth of our NSA, videophone Age: we're all in technological glass houses.

Throw stones at one's own peril.

Yes a waste
but well, at least it is a respite from Sir Lecture a Lot etc...ad nauseum

Sorry to say that this is an unappetizing stew of a column that signifies nothing. Combine the Brooks/Coulson affair, a stale account of the implosion of the Johnny-Joanna Carson marriage, and some inconsequential remarks by Daniel Craig. Stir and print.

What a waste of an enviable place on the New York Times's global platform. Mo, you can and should do better than this.

Buddy, I agree.

The world would be an uninteresting place if it were filled with nothing but finance & accounting majors. In fact, my undergrad. major was political science. Personally, I find financial markets fascinating but I readily admit that I can't stand talking to a college business major.
When did you get you PhD?  I would bet not any time in the past ten years.  Things have changed- and definitely for the worse.
Even if you do get an academic job, it's not what it used to be. This disillusioned computer science professor explains it well: http://cs.unm.edu/~terran/academic_blog/?p=113

I agree with the comment about treating academia like a business. IMO, we have started selling diplomas instead of educations in the broad sense of the term. I never intended to earn a living directly from my Ph.D.  I did it in a field that interested me and loved every minute of it in spite of the fact that I did it while working.  The nice thing is to find out afterwards that it has become a great asset for me in the job market and has enhanced my life in more ways than I can count.  No regrets here.

You are right. Education has been commodified along with health care and other services which should be part of the public patrimony. Most education policies of late have further implemented the privatization of education to the detriment of public schools. And these are symptomatic of the development (should I say stagnation) of a capitalism whose better days are long past in fading back in the distance and that will attempt to extract rent from wherever it can.

I can't thank the NYT enough for this article and the organizations/websites it references! Unlike many in the humanites, my STEM PhD made me employable. I had a tenure-track teaching position for about 2.5 years. I hated every minute of it. The downside of STEM is that you are expected to bring in a huge amount of grant money. The pressure was intense. There was no way to get tenure and be the kind of mother I wanted to be.

I may be mistaken, but it seems to me that the push to treat academia like a business started this downhill slide. Academic pursuits are no longer appreciated for their own sake, it seems. Our society used to be able to support humanites graduates. What happened?

The website "How to Leave Academia" is a treasure. I read there about how grad students are socialized to think that leaving academia means that you failed. So true. I am working now as a lecturer, which some call indentured servitude. There is a lot to think about. So glad to find I am not alone and that there is support out there.

They refuse to treat people equitably because they can.  And they can because there are way too many people willing to sell themselves short.  The point is: people do not up and leave.  If they did, institutions would figure out how to pay them more.

Don't worry about not having the PhD. Most people are hired for their ability to do a job, and not specifically for their educational background. In fact, a PhD is considered a liability in many positions. The hiring managers who do not have one will see you as overqualified or uninterested in doing the "real" work.

Too many people choose to do PhDs as a way out of choosing a career post-BA. Despite having the offer of a PhD route at my university, I chose to go into publishing and marketing instead. I learned a lot, earned more money than my PhD-pursuing peers and had more freedom.

The downside? Now in my mid-30s, I've taken a career break to have children and I am worried that reentering the workplace will be tough. I may have to start at the bottom again and wish I had a PhD now to prove my academic credentials to employers. A PhD is a good qualification to have later on in life when seeking higher-level roles. When you 'only' have a Masters or BA, you can slide down the career ladder quickly.
that history is not unusual for your period........

No one is going to pay that kind of money to anyone unless they are making a pile of money. for the employer......and for that ROI they will have to lawyer up and figure out how to work the system.......basically steal without going to jail......which is what Madoff failed to do prior to the meltdown..........

MOOCs can be 'open' even when they charge some sort of fee. The money will have to come from somewhere. They will be 'open' if anyone, anywhere in the world can enroll and participate without a complex and exclusive admission process. They will be 'open' if someone can complete degree requirements by taking courses from different faculties, without being trapped within the walls of one institution.

to clarify, open doesn't mean free it  means "openly licensed" as in licensed under Creative Commons various levels of licensing.  This is not to say open shouldn't be free or can't be free but open refers to the licensing not the price, in my understanding.  I have no idea what the licensing structure of the Georgia Tech program. If it is proprietary licensing, with no provisions to reuse/redistribute/remix, than saying it isn't open is valid critique

Can we please stop calling programs such as Georgia's Masters program "MOOCs"? The first "O" stands for "open" as in "free-- open to anyone without regard to payment". As soon as you charge a dime, you're not a MOOC. That doesn't mean everything should be free but we should be careful not to bait-and-switch.
